Description: CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION WILL CONDUCT MARINE DEBRIS EDUCATION, REMOVAL AND MONITORING ACTIVITIES IN THE TIJUANA RIVER NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE (TRNERR) AND BORDER FIELD STATE PARK IN SAN DIEGO COUNTY, CALIFORNIA. THE PROJECT GOALS INCLUDE: INSTALLING AND IMPLEMENTING NEW INNOVATIVE ELEMENTS TO A TRASH BOOM CURRENTLY INSTALLED AT THE PROJECT SITE AND ASSESSING THE NEW SYSTEM'S PERFORMANCE THROUGHOUT THE DURATION OF THE PROJECT. THE SYSTEM WILL BE MONITORED THROUGHOUT THE AWARD AND DEBRIS WILL BE REMOVED FROM THE TRASH BOOM BOTH MECHANICALLY AND BY HAND. THIS PROJECT IS EXPECTED TO REMOVE APPROXIMATELY 30-70 TONS OF DEBRIS PER YEAR. ADDITIONALLY, THE NEW SYSTEM AND ASSOCIATED REMOVALS ARE EXPECTED TO PROVIDE BOTH ECONOMIC AND LONG TERM HEALTH BENEFITS TO LOCAL RESIDENTS IN THE COMMUNITIES SURROUNDING THE PROJECT SITES. OUTREACH VIDEOS WILL BE CREATED TO SHARE LESSONS LEARNED FROM THE INTERCEPTION SYSTEM ADAPTATION PROCESS INCLUDING DIVERSE TRINATIONAL (U.S

LYNNHAVEN RIVER NOW WILL REMOVE 100 ABANDONED AND DERELICT VESSELS ACROSS THE ENTIRE COASTAL ZONE OF THE COMMONWEALTH OF VIRGINIA. MINOR RESTORATION AND MONITORING WILL OCCUR AT PROJECT SITES FOLLOWING REMOVALS. OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES WILL BE CONDUCTED TO ASSIST IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF A FUTURE ABANDONED AND DERELICT VESSEL REMOVAL AND PREVENTION PROGRAM FOR VIRGINIA. REGIONAL OUTREACH EFFORTS WILL BE TARGETED TO BOAT OWNERS AND COMMUNITIES SURROUNDING VESSELS TARGETED FOR REMOVAL (INCLUDING IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES) AND WILL TAKE PLACE IN A VARIETY OF VIRTUAL AND IN-PERSON FORMATS. MEETINGS WILL ALSO BE CONDUCTED TO EXPLORE FIBERGLASS DISPOSAL AS AN ALTERNATIVE FUEL SOURCE TO HELP INFORM THE FEASIBILITY OF ALTERNATIVE DISPOSAL MECHANISMS FOR FIBERGLASS VESSEL HULLS.

THE GULF OF MEXICO ALLIANCE WILL CONDUCT A 4-YEAR PROJECT TO REMOVE LARGE MARINE DEBRIS ITEMS, PRIMARILY ABANDONED AND DERELICT VESSELS, FROM COASTAL AND MARINE HABITATS ACROSS THE GULF OF MEXICO. THIS WORK WILL BE COMPLETED THROUGH A TIERED APPROACH FOCUSED ON FIRST 96 KNOWN DERELICT VESSELS IN TEXAS, MISSISSIPPI, AND ALABAMA AND THEN NEWLY IDENTIFIED LARGE MARINE DEBRIS ITEMS IN ALL FIVE STATES. GOMA WILL PARTNER WITH THE MISSISSIPPI STATE UNIVERSITY COASTAL AND MARINE EXTENSION PROGRAM AND GULF STATE NATURAL RESOURCE AGENCIES TO COMPLETE THESE ACTIVITIES. THE REMOVALS WILL BENEFIT NOAA TRUST RESOURCES THROUGH ACTIVE REMOVAL OF MANY TONS OF MARINE DEBRIS, ASSESSMENT OF THE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS PRE AND POST REMOVAL, AND INCREASED AWARENESS OF MARINE DEBRIS IMPACTS.

BOATU.S. FOUNDATION WILL ADMINISTER A NATIONAL COMPETITIVE GRANT COMPETITION FOR THE REMOVAL OF ABANDONED AND DERELICT VESSELS. IT IS EXPECTED 20-75 ORGANIZATIONS WILL RECEIVE GRANTS TO REMOVE ABANDONED AND DERELICT VESSELS FROM THIS COMPETITION. ADDITIONALLY, THIS PROJECT INCLUDES THE DEVELOPMENT OF A NATIONAL ABANDONED AND DERELICT VESSEL DATABASE TO TRACK LOCATIONS OF ABANDONED AND DERELICT VESSELS AND REMOVAL EFFORTS. OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES INCLUDE A MULTI-DAY NATIONAL CONFERENCE ON BOATING-RELATED DEBRIS DISPOSAL TO CREATE PEER-TO-PEER RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN MARINE INDUSTRY, DISPOSAL COMPANIES, AND GOVERNMENT ENTITIES. OTHER OUTREACH ACTIVITIES INCLUDE CREATING BOTH A VIDEO SERIES HIGHLIGHTING SELECTED REMOVAL PROJECTS AND A DOCUMENTARY ON ABANDONED AND DERELICT VESSELS.

NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY FOUNDATION PROPOSES THE HIGH-IMPACT AND LARGE MARINE DEBRIS REMOVAL THROUGHOUT THE NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY SYSTEM PROJECT TO REMOVE LARGE MARINE DEBRIS FROM FIVE NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARIES AND TWO TRIBAL ANCESTRAL WATERS LOCATED OFF THE COASTS OF WASHINGTON, CALIFORNIA, TEXAS, AND LOUISIANA. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL RUN FROM JULY 1, 2023 TO JUNE 30, 2026. THE PROJECT WILL REMOVE ABANDONED AND DERELICT VESSELS, DERELICT FISHING GEAR, DERELICT STRUCTURES, AND OTHER LARGE SCALE DEBRIS. TARGETS HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED IN EACH SANCTUARY IN COORDINATION WITH SANCTUARY STAFF AND PARTNERS. THE PROPOSAL OUTCOMES INCLUDE: (1) REMOVE 20 ABANDONED AND DERELICT VESSELS AND OTHER LARGE DERELICT STRUCTURES FROM OLYMPIC COAST NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY AND NEAH BAY IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE MAKAH AND QUILEUTE TRIBES; (2) REMOVAL OF THREE LARGE PIECES OF EQUIPMENT RELATED TO THE OIL AND GAS INDUSTRY, RESEARCH, AND SALVAGE ACTIVITIES LOCATED AT DEPTHS GREATER THAN 150 FEET IN FLO

THE UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA FAIRBANKS WILL ESTABLISH A LONG-TERM CENTER FOR MARINE DEBRIS BASED IN KODIAK, ALASKA. THIS CENTER, A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT WITH ALASKA SEA GRANT AND THE OCEAN PLASTICS RECOVERY PROJECT, WILL BOTH FACILITATE AND SUPPORT TARGETED REMOVAL OPERATIONS, AND WORK TO SERVE THE IDENTIFIED AND EMERGENT NEEDS OF THE MARINE DEBRIS COMMUNITY ACROSS THE STATE, THROUGH ACTIVITIES INCLUDING DEBRIS COLLECTION, MONITORING, ANALYSIS, TRANSPORT, AND DISPOSAL. THERE IS AN ACTIVE, GROWING, AND DEDICATED MARINE DEBRIS COMMUNITY ACROSS ALASKA WHO ARE CONFRONTING MARINE DEBRIS CHALLENGES THAT ARE UNIQUE TO ALASKA. THE CENTER WILL WORK TO SUPPORT SUCH GROUPS IN IDENTIFYING AND IMPLEMENTING EFFECTIVE MARINE DEBRIS REMOVAL PROJECTS, AND WILL ADVANCE EFFORTS TO OPTIMIZE DISPOSAL OPTIONS AVAILABLE TO THEM. TO DO SO, THE CENTER WILL ADMINISTER A COMPETITIVE PROCESS TO SUB-AWARD FUNDING FOR THE REMOVAL OF DEBRIS THROUGHOUT ALASKA, WHICH WILL BE IN ALIGNMENT WITH PRIORITIES OF THE REGION, AND

VIRGINIA INSTITUTE OF MARINE SCIENCE WILL REMOVE AND RECYCLE ABANDONED TRAPS FROM CHESAPEAKE BAY AND WILL ALSO ADMINISTER A COMPETITIVE GRANT PROGRAM FOR THE REMOVAL OF DERELICT FISHING TRAPS ACROSS THE COUNTRY. A COMMUNICATIONS STRATEGY AND ASSOCIATED TOOLS WILL BE DEVELOPED TO SUPPORT THE PROJECT'S OUTREACH EFFORTS, INCLUDING INFORMATIONAL WEBINARS FOR POTENTIAL GRANT APPLICANTS AND A WEBSITE WITH A METRIC DASHBOARD. VIRGINIA INSTITUTE OF MARINE SCIENCE WILL PARTNER WITH KENAH CONSULTING TO ENHANCE PARTICIPATION IN THE PROGRAM BY UNDERREPRESENTED COMMUNITIES. THIS WORK WILL COORDINATE OUTREACH TO TRIBES AND ASSIST IN TRIBAL CAPACITY BUILDING, WHERE APPROPRIATE.  CURRENT EFFORTS TO ADDRESS THE ISSUE OF DERELICT FISHING GEAR ARE DISCONNECTED. THIS IMPORTANT WORK WILL NOT ONLY ALLOW ORGANIZATIONS TO ACCESS FUNDS FOR REMOVAL OF DERELICT FISHING TRAPS, BUT IT WILL ALSO COORDINATE TRACKING, MONITORING, AND ASSESSMENT OF THESE REMOVAL EFFORTS IN A MANNER THAT PROVIDES CONSISTENCY IN DATA

SINGLE-USE PLASTIC CONSUMPTION HAS BEEN STEADILY RISING SINCE THE 1950'S, LEADING TO AN INCREASE OF GARBAGE IN OUR RIVERS, STREAMS, AND OCEANS. IT IS ESTIMATED THAT EVERY YEAR, 11 MILLION METRIC TONS OF PLASTICS ENTER OUR OCEANS, ADDING TO THE 200 MILLION METRIC TONS CURRENTLY CIRCULATING. THE UNIVERSITY OF FLORIDA IS WORKING TO ADDRESS THIS ISSUE BY PARTNERING WITH LOCAL GOVERNMENTS AND FLORIDA'S AQUATIC PRESERVE SYSTEMS TO IMPLEMENT OPERATION TRAP, A PROJECT DESIGNED TO INTERCEPT LITTER AT THE SOURCE BEFORE IT REACHES FLORIDA'S COASTAL WATERWAYS. OPERATION TRAP FOCUSES ON THE INSTALLATION OF INTERCEPTION TECHNOLOGIES, DATA COLLECTION, AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT TO ENCOURAGE THE REDUCTION OF SINGLE USE ITEMS, WHILE PHYSICALLY INTERCEPTING AND PREVENTING LITTER FROM ENTERING FLORIDA'S AQUATIC PRESERVES IN THE BIG BEND AND NATURE COAST REGION OF FLORIDA'S GULF COAST. THESE PRESERVES ENCOMPASS ROUGHLY ONE MILLION ACRES OF CONTINUOUS, STATE MANAGED SUBMERGED RESOURCES. THE PROJECT IS DEPLOY

THIS AWARE IS AIMED AT REDUCING THE IMPACTS OF MARINE DEBRIS WITHIN THE PAPAHANAUMOKUAKEA MARINE NATIONAL MONUMENT (PMNM). THE EXPECTED OUTCOME OF THIS AGREEMENT IS THE REDUCTION OF NEAR-SHORE AND SHORELINE MARINE DEBRIS WITHIN THE PMNM, ACHIEVED THROUGH THE STRATEGIC REMOVAL OF MARINE DEBRIS (E.G. DERELICT FISHING GEAR, ABANDONED AND DERELICT VESSELS, AND OCEAN PLASTICS), AND ASSOCIATED COORDINATION AND CAPACITY BUILDING ACTIVITIES RELATED TO REMOVAL IN THE REGION. NOAA EXPECTS THAT THE MAJORITY OF FUNDING AWARDED TO NFWF THROUGH THIS AGREEMENT WILL SUPPORT SUB-AWARD(S) TO QUALIFIED ENTITIES TO IMPLEMENT PROJECTS OR PROGRAMS THAT WILL COORDINATE AND SUPPORT EFFORTS TO REDUCE, REMOVE AND BETTER UNDERSTAND THE SOURCES AND IMPACTS OF MARINE DEBRIS ON PMNM WILDLIFE AND HABITATS. WITH THESE FUNDS, NOAA AND NFWF WILL REDUCE THE AMOUNT OF MARINE DEBRIS TO AMOUNTS AT OR BELOW WHAT CAN BE REMOVED BY AN ANNUAL OR BI-ANNUAL PROGRAM AND TO REDUCE THE INCIDENCE OF ENTANGLEMENT AND HABITAT DAMAGE I

THE CLEAN WATER FUND (CWF) RETHINK DISPOSABLE IS A DATA-DRIVEN SOURCE REDUCTION PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES DIRECT ASSISTANCE TO FOOD BUSINESSES, INSTITUTIONS, AND GOVERNMENTS TO CONVERT TO REUSABLE FOODWARE. THIS 24-MONTH PROJECT WILL EXPAND CWF'S SUCCESSFUL CALIFORNIA PROGRAM TO OVER SIX STATES ON THE EAST COAST AND GREAT LAKES. CWF HAS SELECTED PRIME BUSINESS DISTRICTS, INSTITUTIONS, GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, AND ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE COMMUNITIES IN UP TO EIGHT TARGETED COASTAL AND GREAT LAKE STATES ACROSS THE COUNTRY - AMONG THEM, CALIFORNIA, MINNESOTA, MICHIGAN, NEW JERSEY, PENNSYLVANIA, CONNECTICUT, RHODE ISLAND AND MASSACHUSETTS. IT TARGETS THE LARGEST SOURCE OF INLAND TRASH - SINGLE-USE FOOD AND BEVERAGE PACKAGING. CLEAN WATER FUND WILL DEVELOP A TRAINING PROGRAM, MATERIALS, DATA MANAGEMENT TOOLS AND A COMMUNICATIONS STRATEGY TO SUPPORT PROGRAM EXPANSION. THE PROJECT WILL ELIMINATE 5-8 MILLION PIECES OF SINGLE-USE FOODWARE PER YEAR GOING FORWARD BY CONVERTING 120-150 BUSINESSES AND 3 INST

THE VERMILION SEA INSTITUTE (VSI) AND ASSOCIATED VERMILION SEA FIELD STATION (VSFS) COORDINATES THE AVENTUREROS, AN ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAM FOCUSED ON PROVIDING SCHOOL-AGED YOUTH IN BAH A DE LOS  NGELES WITH OPPORTUNITIES FOR HANDS-ON CONSERVATION EXPERIENCE TO FOSTER STEWARDSHIP AND GROW THE NEXT GENERATION OF CONSERVATION LEADERS ON THE THE GULF OF CALIFORNIA, MEXICO.  THIS PROJECT, DRIVEN BY YOUTH LEADERSHIP, WILL TAKE SIGNIFICANT STEPS TOWARD PREVENTING DEBRIS FROM ENTERING THE BAH A DE LOS  NGELES BIOSPHERE RESERVE IN THE GULF OF CALIFORNIA. THE AVENTUREROS, WILL BE THE DRIVERS FOR EACH ASPECT OF THE PROJECT. THE PURPOSE OF THIS APPROACH, BOTH IN THE PROGRAM GENERALLY AND IN THIS PROJECT, IS TO DEVELOP A GENERATION OF ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE MAKERS ON THE BAJA PENINSULA AND TO ENSURE THAT THE COMMUNITY OF BAH A DE LOS  NGELES, MEXICO IS WELL-PREPARED TO PREVENT MARINE DEBRIS FOR DECADES TO COME. THE PROJECT WILL CONDUCT AND ENACT PLACE-BASED DEBRIS PREVENTION PROGRAMS INCLUDI

THE GOAL OF THIS PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO REDUCE BARRIERS TO MARINE DEBRIS PREVENTION IN THE TEXAS RECREATIONAL FISHERY. THE TYPES OF MARINE DEBRIS TO BE ADDRESSED ARE MONOFILAMENT FISHING LINE AND SINGLE-USE PLASTIC ITEMS COMMONLY USED DURING FISHING ACTIVITIES. THE TARGET AUDIENCE IS THE TEXAS  RECREATIONAL FISHING INDUSTRY, WHICH IS PRIMARILY A HOOK-AND-LINE FISHERY. PLASTIC DEBRIS IS A WELL- DOCUMENTED ISSUE AFFECTING TEXAS COASTLINES, WITH PLASTIC BOTTLES AND CAPS, FOOD WRAPPERS, PLASTIC  BAGS, AND FISHING LINE CONTRIBUTING TO THE PROBLEM. NEGATIVE IMPACTS OF MARINE DEBRIS ON TEXAS SHORES INCLUDE ENTANGLEMENT OF WILDLIFE SUCH AS SEABIRDS, SEA TURTLES, AND MARINE MAMMALS; DAMAGE TO LIVING BENTHIC HABITATS; AND UNSIGHTLY BEACHES AND COASTS. TO REDUCE THE AMOUNT OF FISHING LINE AND PLASTIC DEBRIS ORIGINATING FROM TEXAS RECREATIONAL FISHERIES, THE PROJECT AIMS TO 1) EXPAND THE TEXAS MONOFILAMENT RECOVERY AND RECYCLING PROGRAM BY REPLACING DAMAGED OR MISSING BINS WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF A

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RAISE AWARENESS OF AND IMPLEMENT INNOVATIVE SOLUTIONS FOR PREVENTING PLASTIC MARINE DEBRIS FROM ENTERING THE COOK INLET REGION OF ALASKA. THESE INNOVATIONS WILL PROTECT THE MARINE RESOURCES AND THE FOOD SECURITY OF THOSE RELYING ON THESE WATERS BY EFFECTIVELY USING BIO ALTERNATIVES TO EXPANDED POLYSTYRENE (EPS) AND OTHER FOSSIL-BASED AND SINGLE-USE PLASTICS CURRENTLY USED EXTENSIVELY BY THE ALASKAN SEAFOOD INDUSTRY AND FOOD OUTLETS. THIS APPROACH TO ADDRESSING THE MARINE DEBRIS ISSUE IS A HIGH PRIORITY TO OUR NATION AND ALASKA SPECIFICALLY, AS SHOWN IN THE SAVE OUR SEAS 2.0 ACT'S PASSING IN 2020. DURING THE TWO YEAR GRANT PERIOD, THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES WILL BE CONDUCTED: 1) EDUCATE STUDENTS AND THE LOCAL COMMUNITY ON SINGLE-USE PLASTIC ALTERNATIVES AND COMPOSTABLE BIOPLASTICS, 2) ENGAGE STUDENTS AND LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS (LOCAL SEAFOOD PROCESSORS, RECREATIONAL FISHERS, SHELLFISH GROWERS, AND LOCAL AQUACULTURE BUSINESSES) IN DEVELOPING A COMPOSTABLE OPTION

THIS MIAMI-DADE COUNTY PROJECT BEING LED BY THE OCEAN CONSERVANCY AND IN PARTNERSHIP WITH DEBRIS FREE OCEANS AND BIG BLUE AND YOU, WILL TRAIN HIGH SCHOOL YOUTH AMBASSADORS TO ENGAGE LOCAL BUSINESSES ACROSS FIVE ETHNICALLY DIVERSE COMMUNITIES IN CHANGING THEIR BEHAVIORS AND OPERATIONS TO REDUCE SINGLE-USE PLASTICS SUCH AS FOOD AND BEVERAGE CONTAINERS, PLASTIC BAGS AND STRAWS. EIGHT PUBLIC SCHOOLS WILL BE INVOLVED IN THE PROJECT, WITH APPROXIMATELY 120 YOUTH PARTICIPATING OF WHICH OVER 90% IDENTIFY AS A MINORITY. EACH YOUTH WILL COMMIT TO AT LEAST ONE SPECIFIC BEHAVIOR CHANGE OF THEIR OWN AND 24 STUDENTS WILL BECOME PEER MENTORS AND/OR JUNIOR SUSTAINABILITY CONSULTANTS. YOUTH WILL ENGAGE IN PEER-TO-PEER MENTORSHIPS, COMMUNITY EVENTS, SUCH AS CLEANUPS TO PROMOTE ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP, AND THE FINAL CAPSTONE EVENT WHERE THEY WILL PRESENT SUCCESSES. THROUGH THE STUDENT-LED EFFORTS, APPROXIMATELY 240 BUSINESSES WILL BE CONTACTED AND 96 BUSINESSES WILL COMMIT TO THE CAMPAIGN AND RECEIVE C

A SUBSTANTIAL AMOUNT OF MARINE DEBRIS IN THE UNITED STATES ORIGINATES FROM LAND-BASED LITTER. YOUTH UNDER THE AGE OF 19 ARE AN IMPORTANT AGE GROUP TO REACH WITH MESSAGES ABOUT WHAT THEY CAN DO TO PREVENT MARINE DEBRIS, AND MODIFYING LITTER-RELATED BEHAVIORS AMONG YOUTH IN COASTAL WATERSHEDS IS AN IMPORTANT WAY TO REDUCE MARINE DEBRIS. ONE COOL EARTH'S (OCE) EARTH GENIUS PROGRAM BRINGS TOGETHER AN ALLIANCE, INCLUDING NONPROFITS, PUBLIC SCHOOLS, INDIGENOUS GROUPS, AND GOVERNMENT ENTITIES, TO REACH LITTER-AGED YOUTH AND AFFECT THEIR WASTE-DISPOSAL BEHAVIORS. LOCATED ON THE CENTRAL COAST OF CALIFORNIA, THIS PROJECT WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT LOCAL NOAA TRUST RESOURCES: THE CHANNEL ISLANDS AND MONTEREY BAY NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARIES, THE MORRO BAY NATIONAL ESTUARY, AND AREA FISHERIES AND RECREATION. THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON 24 UNDERSERVED K-12 SCHOOL SITES WHERE AN AVERAGE OF 52% STUDENTS ARE NON-WHITE (PREDOMINANTLY LATINX), 50% QUALIFY AS LOW-INCOME, 24% ARE ENGLISH-LANGUAGE LEARNERS (PREDOM

THIS PROJECT IS FOCUSED ON INCREASING THE AWARENESS AND AVOIDANCE OF PLASTIC CONSUMPTION IN THE HOLBOX AND COZUMEL PLASTIC EXCLUSION ZONES. PARLEY AIR IS A SCALABLE STRATEGY TO ADDRESS THE PROBLEM OF PLASTIC POLLUTION AND OTHER OCEAN THREATS THROUGH THREE PILLARS OF ACTION: AVOID. INTERCEPT. REDESIGN. WITH CERTIFIED AIR HOSPITALITY BUSINESSES, A COMMUNITY AND TOURIST AIR AWARENESS AND EDUCATION PROGRAM, AND A HOLISTIC COMMUNITY COLLABORATION & MONITORING PROGRAM, LOCAL RESIDENTS, TOURISTS, COMMERCE NETWORKS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL AUTHORITIES WILL ALL BE CONSULTED AND SUPPORTED BY THE ESTABLISHED PROGRAM ACTIVITIES. THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE ONBOARDING 20 BUSINESSES FOR AN IN-DEPTH PARLEY AIR HOSPITALITY PROGRAM, WHICH WILL REDUCE THE BUSINESSES' PLASTIC WASTE BY AN ESTIMATED 50% AND INCREASE AWARENESS AND EDUCATION IN 80% OF THE HOSPITALITY BUSINESSES ON THE ISLANDS. FURTHERMORE, THE AWARENESS AND EDUCATION PROGRAM WILL IMPROVE AWARENESS IN THE MAJORITY OF ARRIVING TOURISTS BY USING IN

THE PARLEY FOUNDATION WILL BE CONDUCTING IN-PERSON AND VIRTUAL EDUCATION AND OUTREACH COMPLEMENTED WITH OCEAN STEWARDSHIP CLINICS. THESE CLINICS FOCUS ON CREATING A CONNECTION BETWEEN THE OCEAN AND DISADVANTAGED AND UNDERSERVED YOUTH. SIXTEEN OCEAN STEWARDSHIP CLINICS WILL TAKE PLACE FOCUSING ON BRINGING AT LEAST 250 UNDERSERVED YOUTH TO THE OCEAN. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE ACTIVATIONS AT OR IN COORDINATION WITH THE PARLEY AIR (AVOID, INTERCEPT, AND REDESIGN) STATION, A COMMUNITY HUB DEDICATED TO INSPIRING ACTION FOR THE OCEANS AT A COMMUNITY LEVEL. THE STATION IS COMPOSED OF AN OUTDOOR CLASSROOM, UPCYCLING WORKSHOP, MEETING SPACE, AND IMMERSIVE ART EXHIBITS. THE PROJECT HOPES TO REACH AT LEAST 30,000 INDIVIDUALS THROUGH OVER 600 EDUCATIONAL SESSIONS AND WILL UPCYCLE AND REPURPOSE AT LEAST 2500 POUNDS OF MARINE DEBRIS AS AN EDUCATIONAL TOOL.

THE PURPOSE OF THE PROPOSED THREE-YEAR PROJECT IS TO WORK WITH COMMERCIAL SHRIMPERS TO REMOVE MARINE DEBRIS AND ASSESS BOTH THE DISTRIBUTION OF MARINE DEBRIS ENCOUNTERED BY SHRIMPERS AND RECOVERY OF VEGETATION IMPACTED BY MARINE DEBRIS WITHIN AND ALONG THE MISSISSIPPI SOUND. THIS WORK WILL BE DONE THROUGH THE COMPLETION OF SPECIFIC TASKS INCLUDING: 1) CONTINUATION OF A SUCCESSFUL CRAB TRAP REMOVAL INCENTIVE PROGRAM FOR MISSISSIPPI COMMERCIAL SHRIMPERS (I.E., DERELICT TRAP PROGRAM); 2) ADDING OTHER DEBRIS INCLUDING PLASTICS REMOVAL INCENTIVES TO THE DERELICT TRAP PROGRAM INCLUDING EXPANDING AND PILOTING THE FRAMEWORK OF THE DERELICT TRAP PROGRAM TO INCENTIVIZE BROADER MARINE DEBRIS REMOVAL IN MISSISSIPPI STATE TERRITORIAL WATERS AND ADJACENT OFFSHORE FEDERAL WATERS; 3) DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING AN INCENTIVE-BASED OYSTER FARMING GEAR RECOVERY OR REMOVAL PROGRAM FOR OYSTER FARMERS OFFSHORE OF DEER ISLAND, MS AND CONDUCTING ASSESSMENTS VIA UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLES (UAV) AND FIELD SURVEYS

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO REMOVE 60 TONS OF MARINE DEBRIS FROM THE BORDER REGION BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES AND CANADA THROUGH A VESSEL-BASED CLEAN UP IN THE US AND PARTIAL OFFLOAD IN THE PORT OF PRINCE RUPERT, BC, CANADA. THE VESSEL-BASED CLEAN-UP WILL REMOVE APPROXIMATELY 3,600 LBS OF MARINE DEBRIS PER COLLECTION DAY. THE VESSEL-BASED EXPERIENCE WILL PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR OUR UNIVERSITY RESEARCH PARTNERS, FOR HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS OF DIVERSE BACKGROUNDS, AND WILL PROVIDE KNOWLEDGE SHARING AMONG SCIENTISTS, RECYCLING AND RECOVERY EXPERTS, STUDENTS, AND THE TEAM AT OCEAN PLASTICS RECOVERY PROJECT. THE PROJECT AND ASSOCIATED ECONOMIC ACTIVITY WILL PROVIDE JOBS AND ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES FOR LOCAL RESIDENTS. ALL MARINE DEBRIS WILL BE CHARACTERIZED, SORTED, AND SIZE-REDUCED ONBOARD THE CLEAN-UP VESSEL. EACH YEAR, APPROXIMATELY 80% OF THE MARINE DEBRIS WILL BE OFFLOADED AT THE PORT OF PRINCE RUPERT AND SHIPPED TO PROJECT PARTNER ENERKEM IN EDMONTON AB FOR CONVERSION TO METHANO

THIS PROJECT BEING LED BY HAWAII PACIFIC UNIVERSITY'S CENTER FOR MARINE DEBRIS RESEARCH WILL WORK WITH HAWAIIAN LONGLINE FISHERS TO REMOVE 100 METRIC TONS OF DERELICT FISHING GEAR AT SEA IN THE CENTRAL NORTH PACIFIC TO PREVENT DAMAGE TO CORAL REEFS AND ENTANGLEMENT OF ENDANGERED SPECIES, SUCH AS SEA TURTLES AND MONK SEALS, ALONG THE ENTIRE HAWAIIAN ARCHIPELAGO, INCLUDING THE PAPAHANAUMOKUAKEA NATIONAL MARINE MONUMENT. THE PROJECT WILL USE VESSELS OF OPPORTUNITY, SUCH AS THE LONGLINE FLEET AND OTHER COMMERCIAL FISHERS, TO REMOVE THE DERELICT GEAR. TO DO THIS, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL CREATE A GEAR BOUNTY SYSTEM THAT WILL OFFER EXPERIENCED LICENSED COMMERCIAL FISHERS $1 PER POUND OF DERELICT FISHING GEAR REMOVED AT SEA. THIS PROJECT IS BUILDING ON A SIMILAR AND PREVIOUSLY SUCCESSFUL REMOVAL PROJECT.

GILLNETS ARE ONE OF THE MAIN CAUSES OF THE RECENT DECLINE OF MEXICO'S VAQUITA PORPOISE, THE WORLD'S MOST ENDANGERED MARINE MAMMAL, AND CONTINUOUS EFFORT TO KEEP ITS HABITAT FREE OF GILLNETS IS THE MOST EXPEDIENT MEASURE TO PREVENT ITS EXTINCTION. CETACEAN ACTION TREASURY ALONGSIDE MEXICAN PROJECT PARTNERS WHALE MUSEUM, PESCA ABC AND MAREM. THE PRIMARY BENEFIT WILL BE TO MEXICO'S ENDEMIC VAQUITA PORPOISE PHOCOENA SINUS. THE VAQUITA HAS BEEN LISTED AS ENDANGERED ON THE US ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT SINCE 1985.THE PURPOSE OF THIS COLLABORATIVE PROJECT IS TO SEARCH FOR, DETECT AND MARK DERELICT FISHING GEAR, PRIMARILY CONSISTING OF ILLEGAL BOTTOMSET GILLNETS, FOR REMOVAL BY MEXICAN AUTHORITIES AND THE PARTNERS, AS WELL AS REPORT THE ILLEGAL PLACEMENT OF SUCH NETS BY FISHERMEN FOR ENFORCEMENT ACTION BY MEXICAN AUTHORITIES. IT IS EXPECTED THAT THE PROJECT WILL LOCATE AND ASSIST IN REMOVAL OF FROM 1-8 TONS OR APPROXIMATELY 260 GILLNETS, WITH THE LARGE-MESH TOTOABA TYPE GILLNET BEING THE TOP PRIOR

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS SPECIFICALLY FOCUSED ON THE SUCCESSFUL REMOVAL OF DERELICT FISHING GEAR IN SEQUIM & DISCOVERY BAYS WHILE ENGAGING THE LOCAL COMMUNITY IN IDENTIFICATION AND REMOVAL ACTIVITIES AND CREATING SUSTAINED EDUCATION AND PREVENTION ACTIVITIES IN THE BROADER COMMUNITY.  TO ACCOMPLISH THESE BROAD GOALS THE BAY WILL BE SURVEYED THROUGH THE USE OF SIDESCAN SONAR, FOLLOWED BY EXPERIENCED FISHING GEAR RECOVERY DIVERS RECOVERING THE IDENTIFIED CRAB POTS. AN ESTIMATED 550 CRAB POTS WILL BE REMOVED AND DOCUMENTED FOR POT TYPE, DEPTH, STATE AT RECOVERY TIME, LIVE / DEAD SPECIES, AND DENSITY. FOLLOWING RECOVERY, CRAB POTS WILL BE SORTED BY OWNERSHIP AND RETURNED TO THE PROPER OWNERS.  TRIBAL EQUIPMENT WILL BE RETURNED TO THE APPROPRIATE TRIBAL GROUP AND FACILITATED BY THE JAMESTOWN TRIBE.  SERVICEABLE POTS WILL BE RETURNED TO SERVICE BY THE RECEIVING GROUP (PUGET SOUND ANGLERS OR TRIBE).  NON-SERVICEABLE POTS WILL BE DISMANTLED INTO THEIR BASE COMPONENTS AND RECYCLED. DU

THIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT ANNUAL, COMMUNITY CLEANUPS ON UNINHABITED CAYS AND MANGROVE FORESTS IN ST. THOMAS, ST. JOHN, AND ST, CROIX, USVI. THESE EFFORTS WILL COLLECT KEY DATA ON DEBRIS COMPOSITION, LOCATION, QUANTITY FOR THESE LOCATIONS, AS WELL AS MORE INTENSIVE APPLICATION OF NOAA'S SHORELINE SURVEY GUIDE METHODS FOR MANGROVE SHORELINES, INCLUDING SUB-ANNUAL ACCUMULATION DATA. TO ACCOMPANY THE REMOVAL EFFORTS, THE PROJECT WILL TRAIN ONE GRADUATE STUDENT AT THE UNIVERSITY OF THE VIRGIN ISLANDS (UVI), A HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGE AND UNIVERSITY (HBCU) AND UP TO 420 CITIZEN SCIENTISTS IN MARINE DEBRIS REMOVAL AND DATA COLLECTION TECHNIQUES, AND WILL DEVELOP OUTREACH MATERIALS FOCUSED ON MARINE DEBRIS AND MANGROVE AND CAY CONSERVATION, DIRECTED TOWARDS KEY, TERRITORIAL STAKEHOLDER GROUPS, INCLUDING RESOURCE MANAGERS, FISHERS, AND BOATERS.

NATIONAL FISH AND WILDLIFE FOUNDATION (NFWF) PROPOSES TO CONTINUE ITS PARTNERSHIP WITH THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) MARINE DEBRIS PROGRAM, TO SUPPORT PROJECTS TO ASSESS, REMOVE, AND DISPOSE OF MARINE DEBRIS IN AND AROUND COASTAL COMMUNITIES WITH AN EMPHASIS ON DEBRIS WITHIN COMMUNITIES IMPACTED FROM THE 2020-2021 HURRICANE SEASONS. LIMITED FUNDING MAY ALSO BE MADE AVAILABLE TO BUILD CAPACITY WITHIN STATES AND TERRITORIES TO BE BETTER PREPARED TO MANAGE MARINE DEBRIS AFTER THESE TYPES OF EVENTS. THE PARTNERSHIP WILL AWARD FUNDING TO AFFECTED COMMUNITIES MADE AVAILABLE FROM THE EXTENDING GOVERNMENT FUNDING AND DELIVERING EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE ACT, 2021, PUB. L. 117-43. THESE INVESTMENTS WILL ENABLE COMMUNITIES TO BETTER RECOVER FROM THE STORMS OF 2020-2021 AND PREVENT FURTHER DAMAGE TO HABITATS AND SPECIES FROM SCOURING AND ENTANGLEMENT. FUNDS THROUGH THIS AGREEMENT WILL BE AWARDED AS SUB-AWARDS UNDER NFWF'S HURRICANE RESPONSE MARINE DEBRIS REMOVAL FUND AND O

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT THE GULF OF MEXICO AND THE MEXICAN CARIBBEAN BY IMPLEMENTING THE PARLEY'S AIR STRATEGY TO AVOID, INTERCEPT AND REDESIGN, CREATING END TO END SOLUTIONS FOR MARINE DEBRIS WITH A FOCUS ON FISHING GEAR IN ORDER TO PREVENT IT FROM ENTERING THE GULF OF MEXICO AND TO REMOVE EXISTING MARINE DEBRIS.   THERE WILL BE 3 PROJECT COMPONENTS: (1) FISHING GEAR COLLECTION AND NET UPCYCLING, (2) CLEANUPS IN REMOTE AREAS (3) EDUCATION AND ENGAGEMENT. THE INITIATIVE WILL REMOVE AN EXPECTED 500,000 POUNDS OF FISHING GEAR AND MARINE DEBRIS, UPCYCLE 150,000 POUNDS OF NYLON NETS, ENGAGE APPROXIMATELY 1,300 FISHERS AND EDUCATE OVER 20,000 PEOPLE DIRECTLY THROUGHOUT MEXICO. THE FIRST COMPONENT OF THIS PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT A FISHING GEAR COLLECTION SYSTEM FOR ALL FISHING GEAR AND AN INNOVATIVE SOLUTION FOR NYLON FISHING NETS IN ORDER TO PREVENT NEW DERELICT FISHING GEAR. PARLEY WILL INSTALL AND OPERATE A NET UPCYCLING STATION FOR MONOFILAMENT NYLON NETS IN ORDER TO T

THE GULF OF MAINE ASSOCIATION (GOMA) WILL PARTNER WITH URBAN HARBORS INSTITUTE, SURFRIDER FOUNDATION, CENTER FOR COASTAL STUDIES, BLUE OCEAN SOCIETY, NH COASTAL PROGRAM, AND HUNTSMAN MARINE SCIENCE CENTRE TO CREATE AN INTERNATIONAL COLLABORATIVE APPROACH TO ADDRESSING THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROBLEM OF PLASTIC AND OTHER MARINE DEBRIS IN THE GULF OF MAINE ECOSYSTEM.   PARTNERS WILL WORK TOGETHER TO IMPLEMENT GULF-WIDE AND TARGETED ACTIONS TO REDUCE AND PREVENT THE INTRODUCTION OF MARINE DEBRIS INTO THE GULF OF MAINE IN SUPPORT OF THE 2019 GULF OF MAINE MARINE DEBRIS ACTION PLAN.   MEMBERS OF THE PROJECT TEAM BRING THE EXPERTISE AND EXPERIENCE NEEDED TO SUCCESSFULLY IMPLEMENT COASTAL CLEANUPS, MARINE DEBRIS TRACKING, OUTREACH AND AWARENESS PROGRAMS, INITIATIVES TO ENGAGE BUSINESSES AND CITIZENS IN REDUCING SOURCES OF MARINE DEBRIS, AND TO EXPAND BOTH A REGIONAL DATABASE FOR ABANDONED DERELICT FISHING GEAR FOUND ON SHORELINES AND A ROPE RECYCLING/REPURPOSING PROGRAM,  THE GOMA, WITH ITS PAR

SIGNIFICANT REDUCTION OF MARINE DEBRIS IN THE UNITED STATES REQUIRES ADDRESSING SYSTEMIC CHALLENGES IN THE BINATIONAL TIJUANA RIVER WATERSHED. EVIDENCE AND LESSONS LEARNED FROM DECADES OF THE TIJUANA RIVER NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE'S (TRNERR) FOCUSED EFFORTS ON ADDRESSING MARINE DEBRIS HAS ILLUMINATED AREAS OF GREATEST NEED: IMMEDIATE AND INNOVATIVE STRATEGIES/APPROACHES; LEADERSHIP OF ELECTED OFFICIALS AND DECISION-MAKERS IN THE AREA OF SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT; INCREASED KNOWLEDGE AND TRAINING; FLOOD RESILIENCE; AND DETECTION AND REMOVAL.   WITH REQUESTED FUNDS, OVER TWO YEARS, WE PROPOSE TO PREVENT AND REMOVE MARINE DEBRIS BY: (1) PILOTING A COMMUNITY-LED CIRCULAR ECONOMY APPROACH THROUGH REUSE AND INCOME GENERATION ; (2) ESTABLISHING AND IMPLEMENTING A CROSS-BORDER MARINE DEBRIS LEADERSHIP ACADEMY; (3) IMPROVING BINATIONAL FLOOD EMERGENCY RESPONSE AND RESILIENCE; (4) PROVIDING AN EXEMPLARY MODEL OF LAND-BASED MARINE DEBRIS CAPTURE AND CHARACTERIZATION; AND (5) PROTECTING

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CLEAN 50 MILES OF SHORELINE IN THE YAKUTAT BOROUGH, ON THE FOLLOWING FIVE BEACHES; TSIU, CAPE YAKUTAGA, CANNON BEACH, BLACKSAND SPIT, AND THE ITALIO BEACH, AND TO REMOVE AN ESTIMATED 107,790 POUNDS OF MARINE DEBRIS. EACH OF THE FIVE BEACHES LISTED ABOVE WILL BE SURVEYED TO DOCUMENT THE MARINE DEBRIS WITH PICTURES, VIDEOS, AND DRONE FOOTAGE THAT SHOW DIFFERENT TYPES OF DEBRIS AND ACCUMULATE AMOUNTS, AND PREDICT THE APPROXIMATE WEIGHT OF DEBRIS COLLECTED. THE MARINE DEBRIS COLLECTED WILL BE SORTED BY CATEGORY AND WEIGHED. ONCE THE MARINE DEBRIS HAS BEEN SORTED, WEIGHED, AND DOCUMENTED, A REPORT WILL BE PREPARED OF THIS PROJECT. THE REPORT WILL INCLUDE BEFORE AND AFTER PICTURES/VIDEOS OF THE FIVE SHORELINE AREAS IN THE PROJECT, THE TYPES OF MARINE DEBRIS FOUND ON EACH BEACH, THE WEIGHT OF DEBRIS, ALONG WITH THE DATES OF THE REMOVAL ACTIVITY. DEBRIS THAT IS SALVAGED WILL BE DOCUMENTED BY WEIGHT AND TYPE, AND HOW IT WILL BE REUSED OR REPURPOSED. THE EDUCA

THE NURDLE PATROL PROGRAM, INITIATED BY THE LEADING PI TUNNELL AT UTMSI, HAS BEEN SUCCESSFUL IN ENHANCING AWARENESS OF PLASTIC POLLUTION AMONG EDUCATORS, THE PUBLIC AND MULTIPLE STAKEHOLDERS, AND FURTHER IN THE LEGISLATION OF ZERO-TOLERANCE NURDLE SPILL BY MANUFACTURERS IN TEXAS. HOWEVER, PLASTIC POLLUTION IN MARINE ENVIRONMENTS HAS NO BORDER. THIS IS PARTICULARLY TRUE WHEN CONSIDERING THAT THE UNITED STATES AND MEXICO ARE WELL CONNECTED THROUGH GULF OF MEXICO COASTAL CURRENTS, WHICH CARRY THE PLASTIC NURDLES AND SPREAD THEM AROUND ALONG THE WAY. THEREFORE, THERE IS A CRITICAL NEED TO EXPAND THE NURDLE PATROL PROGRAM TO MEXICO IN ORDER TO ACCOMPLISH THE PREVENTION AND REMOVAL OF THE NURDLES ALONG THE GULF OF MEXICO SHORELINE. THEREFORE, THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO EXPAND THE NURDLE PATROL CITIZEN SCIENCE PROGRAM ACROSS THE UNITED STATES AND INTO MEXICO, TO DOCUMENT PLASTIC PELLET POLLUTION IN RIVERS, BAYS, AND BEACHES ALONG THE GULF OF MEXICO, AND TO HELP IDENTIFY SOURCES AND TARG

THE PROJECT WILL, OVER TWO YEARS, REDUCE MARINE DEBRIS ORIGINATING IN LOS LAURELES CANYON, A TRIBUTARY OF THE TIJUANA RIVER, FROM ENTERING THE PACIFIC OCEAN AT THE UNITED STATES-MEXICO BORDER. THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE THE ECOLOGICAL HEALTH OF 18,987 ACRES OF PROTECTED AREAS IN THE UNITED STATES INCLUDING: THE 2,293-ACRE TIJUANA RIVER NATIONAL ESTUARINE RESEARCH RESERVE; 1,800-ACRE TIJUANA RIVER VALLEY REGIONAL PARK PRESERVE, HOME TO OVER 300 BIRD SPECIES; AND THE 1,930-ACRE TIJUANA RIVER MOUTH STATE MARINE CONSERVATION AREA, A CRITICAL HABITAT FOR LEOPARD SHARKS, BOTTLENOSE DOLPHINS, AND CALIFORNIA SPINY LOBSTER. IN BAJA CALIFORNIA, THE PROJECT WILL HELP REDUCE MARINE DEBRIS ON TIJUANA'S BEACHES AND PREVENT DEBRIS FROM ENTERING PACIFIC ISLANDS BIOSPHERE RESERVE. THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT IMPORTANT OUTDOOR RECREATION AREAS WITHIN LOW INCOME, PARK-POOR COMMUNITIES IN THE BORDER REGION THAT ARE CONTINUOUSLY IMPACTED BY CROSS-BORDER POLLUTION. THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON REDUCING TRANS-BORDER

THIS TRANSBOUNDARY INITIATIVE WILL INVOLVE ACTIVITIES ALONG NORTH AMERICA'S PACIFIC COAST FROM CANADA TO MEXICO, WITH AN INITIAL FOCUS ON PREVENTING GHOST GEAR IN CALIFORNIA STATE WATERS AND MEXICO'S PACIFIC COAST, INCLUDING THE SEA OF CORTEZ. THE PROJECT AIMS TO REDUCE THE SCOPE AND IMPACT OF ABANDONED, LOST OR DISCARDED FISHING GEAR (ALDFG) USING PROVEN BEST PRACTICES THAT PROTECT MARINE LIFE, PRESERVE IMPORTANT ECOSYSTEMS, DECREASE GHOST FISHING, AND OPEN UP INACCESSIBLE FISHING GROUNDS BY REDUCING NAVIGATIONAL HAZARDS. THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES WILL BE IMPLEMENTED OVER THE 2-YEAR PROJECT: LAUNCH THE NORTH AMERICAN NET COLLECTION INITIATIVE (NANCI) BASED ON THE SUCCESSFUL NET POSITIVA PROGRAM, A CIRCULARITY MODEL OF COLLECTING AND TRANSFORMING END-OF-LIFE FISHING NETS INTO HIGH-VALUE CONSUMER GOODS, RESULTING IN AN EXPECTED 200,000 POUNDS OF END-OF-LIFE FISHING NETS TO BE COLLECTED AND RECYCLED; FACILITATE DEVELOPMENT OF MEXICO'S NATIONAL ALDFG ACTION PLAN AND STRENGTHEN REGIONAL LEA

THE NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY FOUNDATION (FOUNDATION) AND COASTSAVERS PROPOSE TO COLLABORATE WITH THE OLYMPIC COAST NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY, NET YOUR PROBLEM, THE OCEAN LEGACY FOUNDATION, AND OTHER PARTNERS TO PLAN, COORDINATE, AND IMPLEMENT SIX CLEANUP EVENTS AND AID IN THE PREVENTION OF MARINE DEBRIS ON WASHINGTON'S OUTER COAST, AS WELL AS AT LEAST ONE CLEAN-UP ALONG THE CANADIAN COAST. IT WILL ALSO INCLUDE A FOCUSED EFFORT TO DOCUMENT A BASELINE IN GRAYLAND, WA, AND REMOVE YELLOW AQUACULTURE ROPE, A COMMONLY LITTERED ITEM, AHEAD OF COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS WITH THE SHELLFISH INDUSTRY TO ADDRESS THIS ISSUE. INTRODUCING NEW PARTNERS NET YOUR PROBLEM LLC AND THE OCEAN LEGACY FOUNDATION TO COASTSAVERS OPERATIONS WILL ALLOW VOLUNTEERS TO NOW DISPOSE OF THE COLLECTED MATERIAL IN A NOVEL WAY THAT DEMONSTRATES THIS MATERIAL'S VALUE TO MANUFACTURERS. IN ADDITION TO REMOVAL AND DISPOSAL ACTIVITIES, THIS PROJECT WILL DEMONSTRATE THE VALUE OF BEACH PLASTIC IN MANUFACTURING. NET YOUR PROBLEM WILL

THIS STUDY WILL EXPLORE WHAT PATHWAYS TRANSPORT MARINE DEBRIS FROM UPSTREAM AREAS OF THE GU NICA WATERSHED AND DETERMINE THE FATE OF MARINE DEBRIS EN ROUTE TO THE COAST. A FIELD COMPONENT WILL EXAMINE TEMPORAL AND SPATIAL VARIABILITY OF MARINE DEBRIS TRANSPORT, CONSIDERING WET/DRY SEASONS, TYPE AND QUANTITY OF DEBRIS IN THE RIVER BASED ON LAND USE/COVER (AGRICULTURAL FIELDS, FORESTS, URBAN, ETC.), AND WILL ALSO LOOK AT OTHER LIKELY SOURCES OF DEBRIS SUCH AS FROM STORMWATER AND WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANTS. THIS STUDY WILL ALSO EXAMINE DEBRIS DEGRADATION AND FRAGMENTATION RATES IN THE REGION WITH A COMBINATION OF FIELD AND LABORATORY EXPERIMENTS. THEY WILL CONDUCT A FACTORIAL EXPERIMENT ANALYZING NUMEROUS VARIABLES THAT MIGHT IMPACT FRAGMENTATION AND DEGRADATION RATES, SUCH AS ANALYZING EFFECTS OF SALINITY, UV, AND ENVIRONMENTAL COMPARTMENT (WATER, SAND, SEDIMENT). THEY WILL THEN CONDUCT A REGIONAL ASSESSMENT OF THE GU NICA WATERSHED BY ANALYZING UPSTREAM SOURCES OF MARINE DEBRIS AND THE
MICROPLASTIC DEBRIS: NOVEL TOOLS TO ASSESS THE DEPOSITION AND DEGRADATION IN COASTAL WETLANDS AND OPEN WATER

THIS STUDY WILL COMPARE RELATIVE LOADING OF DEBRIS FROM STORM DRAINS AND HOMELESS ENCAMPMENTS ALONG THE SAN DIEGO RIVER. RESEARCHERS WILL CREATE A STORM DRAIN CAPTURE DATABASE FROM EXISTING DRAINS ACROSS SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA. VIA VISUAL SURVEYS AND UAS, THE PIS WILL CHARACTERIZE THE MATERIALS, SIZES, AND PROPERTIES OF MARINE DEBRIS ORIGINATING FROM HOMELESS ENCAMPMENTS ALONG THE RIVER AND ESTIMATE DEGRADATION/FRAGMENTATION PRIOR TO OUTFALL TO THE OCEAN. PIS WILL DEVELOP REMOTE SENSING AND GEOSPATIAL MODELING TECHNIQUES FOR QUANTIFICATION AND ATTRIBUTION OF RIVER MARGIN DEBRIS (CREATE INVENTORY) AND MEASURE THE EFFECT OF ON-LAND WEATHERING OF RIVER MARGIN DEBRIS, INCLUDING CHANGES IN FRAGMENT SIZE, BUOYANCY, MECHANICAL PROPERTIES AND BIOFILM DEVELOPMENT, AND IMPACTS FOR IN-CHANNEL DEBRIS CAPTURE SOLUTIONS. PIS WILL ALSO INTERVIEW UNHOUSED INDIVIDUALS TO DETERMINE DRIVERS OF DEBRIS-GENERATING BEHAVIORS, SOLICIT SOLUTIONS FOR WASTE REDUCTION THAT RECOGNIZE WASTE MANAGEMENT CHALLENGES IN RI

THE RICHARDSON'S BAY REGIONAL AGENCY WILL REMOVE AT LEAST 30 ABANDONED AND DERELICT VESSELS FROM CALIFORNIA'S RICHARDSON'S BAY. THESE ABANDONED AND DERELICT VESSELS ARE CURRENTLY ANCHORED OR MOORED IN A VITAL EELGRASS BED AND THEIR REMOVAL WILL CREATE LONG-TERM PROTECTION, INCLUDING THE SECOND LARGEST EELGRASS BED IN THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY ESTUARY, HUNDREDS OF THOUSANDS OF WATERBIRDS, COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL PACIFIC HERRING FISHERIES, AND THE LOCAL MARITIME-BASED ECONOMY. THE PROJECT ESTIMATES THESE REMOVED VESSELS WILL BE AT LEAST 200 TONS OF MARINE DEBRIS AND IMPROVE 13 ACRES OF EELGRASS HABITAT. THE EXPECTED TOTAL WEIGHT OF DEBRIS REMOVED IS APPROXIMATELY 200 TONS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO HAVE A MONITORING AND PREVENTION COMPONENT. THE PROJECT WILL MONITOR EELGRASS COVER AND WATERBIRD USE OF RICHARDSON'S BAY TO TRACK IMPROVEMENTS IN THE EELGRASS BED BASED ON VESSEL REMOVAL.
